fields.Title of Contribution: Investigating Condom Use: Exploring Perceived Barriers and Benefits Among South-Asian International College Students in the US
fields.Description/Abstract: Objectives: Despite the substantial presence of South-Asian<br>international students in the United States, research on their<br>sexual health remains limited. The current research aims to fill<br>this gap by investigating condom use and perceived barriers<br>and benefits among South-Asian international students at a<br>Midwest university.<br>Method: A cross-sectional exploratory study design was<br>employed, with data collected through an online survey.<br>Participants (N = 104) completed a questionnaire assessing condom<br>use behavior, perceived barriers, and benefits, as well as<br>demographic information.<br>Results: Results indicated that most participants reported using<br>condoms during sexual intercourse. Common barriers to condom<br>use include embarrassment, concerns about reduced sexual<br>pleasure, and lack of knowledge. Perceived benefits<br>included protection against pregnancy and sexually transmitted<br>infections, providing a sense of security, and reducing<br>worry and anxiety. Logistic regression analysis did not identify<br>statistically significant predictors of condom use among South-<br>Asian international students.<br>Conclusion: Findings underscores the need for culturally sensitive<br>sexual health interventions tailored to the unique needs of<br>this population. Future research should explore additional factors<br>influencing condom use and employ larger sample sizes to<br>enhance understanding and inform targeted interventions.

attachments.filename: Investigating Condom Use  Exploring Perceived Barriers and Benefits Among South-Asian International College Students in the US.pdf
